value: George Washington's Mansion, on his Mount Vernon estate

. Located on the Potomac River, it was the home of George Washington, the first president of the
Mount Vernon is 13 miles south of

. It can be accessed by the George Washington Parkway, which runs through the eastern part of Fairfax County from I-495 to the northwest, to George Washington's plantation to the south. Along the way, it passes through
. Washington National Airport is located along the parkway. Since it is a parkway, it is very pleasantly scenic, and is a tourist attraction in and of itself.
Take the yellow metro line until the last stop at Huntington. Then take the Fairfax connector bus 101
+1 (703) 339-7200 until its last stop at Mount Vernon. Buses depart approximately every hour and the bus ride is about half an hour.
You can take a bus tour from Washington DC to Mount Vernon.

value: +1 (202) 554–5100 offers a tour of Alexandria and Mount Vernon, daily June 15 through Labor Day ($32 adults, $16 children). The fare includes admission to Mount Vernon. Departs 11am from Arlington National Cemetery.
+1 (800) 862-1400 offers another tour of Alexandria and Mount Vernon, daily except New Year, Thanksgiving and Christmas ($55 adults, $30 children). Departs 8am from Union Station.

Getting around is done by walking, which is not hard because Mt. Vernon is a nice small place.

value: Life sized model of General George Washington
name=George Washington's Mount Vernon Estate and Gardens

content=Hours are: April through August, 8AM–5PM, March, September, and October, 9AM–5PM, November through February, 9AM–4PM. Tour the original mansion that George Washington built, lived, and died in. Admission is $15 for adults, $14 for seniors (62+), $7 for children (6-11), and free for children 5 and under.

content=The main attraction: see the rooms that George Washington designed himself and their majestic setting over the Potomac River. This is the only guided portion of the estate, with tours running continuously. Long lines are common so consider doing this first. No photography allowed.
content=The final resting places of George Washington and his wife Martha.
ceremonies take place at 10AM and 2PM, April - October.
name=Donald W. Reynolds Museum and Educational Center
content=Museum of multimedia exhibits which span the life of George Washington. Don't miss the most famous dentures in history!
content=A memorial honoring the slaves who lived and worked at Mount Vernon.
tours are offered at 10AM, 12PM, and 2PM, April - October, and start at the Mansion.
name=George Washington's Whiskey Distillery and Gristmill
directions=Located on Route 235, three miles south of Mount Vernon Estate
price=$4 Adults, $2 Children. Combined with Mount Vernon admission; $2 Adults, $1.50 Children
content=Watch the water-powered mill operate as it did at the time when George Washington developed it as a cutting edge technology.
directions=Departing from the Wharf inside the Mount Vernon Estate
price=In addition to Estate admission: $9 Adults, $5 Children
content=Take in the beautiful setting of the Mount Vernon Estate on a 30-minute narrated tour of the river.
directions=Part of the Mount Vernon Estate; 5 minute walk south of the mansion
content=A 4-acre, colonial farm exhibition highlighting the buildings, tools, and techniques Washington used on the site.
directions=Inside Mount Vernon Estate and Gardens, near the Upper Gardens
content=Colonial gift shop with a feminine theme featuring chinaware, needlework, and garden items.

content=Large gift shop which includes the largest George Washington bookstore in the world, a Christmas Corner with year-round holiday themed gifts, and colonial reproduction gifts. (No admission necessary to enter).
directions=Right by the entrance to the Estate
content=Elegant dining with a colonial theme. Open for lunch and candlelit dinners (reservations recommended).
- Location of the Pentagon, Marine Corps War Memorial (Iwo Jima Statue), and Arlington National Cemetery.
- former hometown to famous American heroes and rebels that claims some of the richest history in the DC metro area
Visitors to President Washington's plantation at Mount Vernon may also want to visit Thomas Jefferson's home,
